  {
    "question": "How does diabetes lead to stroke?",
    "answer": "Diabetes may damage blood vessels in the brain, which can lead to stroke. If any signs of stroke appear, go to the hospital immediately.
Source: HealthHub
https://www.healthhub.sg/a-z/diseases-and-conditions/676/pocket-guide-to-diabetes."
  },
  {
    "question": "How does diabetes lead to heart attack?",
    "answer": "Diabetes may cause damage and blockages to the blood vessels of the heart, which can lead to a heart attack. If you experience chest pains, consult a doctor immediately.
Source: HealthHub
https://www.healthhub.sg/a-z/diseases-and-conditions/676/pocket-guide-to-diabetes."
  },
  {
    "question": "How does diabetes lead to reduced blood circulation?",
    "answer": "Diabetes can reduce or block blood flow to your legs, which may lead to gangrene (tissue death due to loss of blood supply) and even amputation. If you experience pain in the leg brought on by walking that is relieved with rest, or skin turning a darker colour (e.g., brown, purplish-blue, black), see a doctor immediately.
Source: HealthHub
https://www.healthhub.sg/a-z/diseases-and-conditions/676/pocket-guide-to-diabetes."
  },
  {
    "question": "How do I look out for hypoglycaemia?",
    "answer": "These are the common signs and symptoms of hypoglycaemia:
- Hunger
- Changes in behaviour (e.g., moodiness, confusion)
- Unconsciousness
- Tiredness
- Trembling hands/nervousness
- Sweating
- Dizziness/headache
Source: HealthHub
https://www.healthhub.sg/a-z/diseases-and-conditions/676/pocket-guide-to-diabetes."
  },
  {
    "question": "What should I do if I think I have hypoglycaemia?",
    "answer": "Check your blood glucose levels. If it is low, drink half a glass of sweetened beverages (e.g., juice). Alternatively, eat sweets or glucose tablets.
Source: HealthHub
https://www.healthhub.sg/a-z/diseases-and-conditions/676/pocket-guide-to-diabetes."
  },
  {
    "question": "How do I look out for hyperglycaemia?",
    "answer": "These are the common signs and symptoms of hyperglycaemia:
- Feeling tired and weak
- Frequent urination
- Feeling of nausea and/or vomiting
- Blurred vision
- Feeling thirsty all the time
Source: HealthHub
https://www.healthhub.sg/a-z/diseases-and-conditions/676/pocket-guide-to-diabetes."
  },
  {
    "question": "I am sick. What should I do?",
    "answer": "Here are some tips to manage sick days:
- See a doctor
- Get plenty of sleep
- Eat regular meals
- Drink plenty of plain water
- Take medication/insulin as per normal
- Check blood glucose levels more frequently (if unusually high, see a doctor immediately)
Source: HealthHub

    "question": "What kind of carbs should I consume?",
    "answer": "We need carbohydrates in our diet for energy, but some carbs

Diabetes is a chronic condition characterised by high glucose levels. Glucose comes from our food and is also produced by the liver. It is the main source of energy for the body's cells and is transported through the bloodstream. Insulin is the hormone that acts like a 'key' to allow glucose to enter cells. A diet suitable for diabetes is a healthy eating plan that is individualised according to your requirements and lifestyle. It is recommended to achieve at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic physical activity per week, or 30 minutes of exercise 5 times a week. Sugar-free products may still contain carbohydrates in the form of starch that can increase blood glucose levels. Bitter-tasting foods do not help lower blood glucose levels. People with diabetes should avoid alcohol in general. Healthy snacking options include 1 small apple, 10 grapes, 1 wedge of papaya, 1 small pear, 1 medium banana, and 1 glass of low fat or high calcium soy milk with less sugar. Prediabetes is a stage before people develop type 2 diabetes, where blood glucose levels are higher than normal, but not high enough to be considered as frank or overt diabetes. Lifestyle changes such as modest weight loss and moderate-intensity physical activity can help manage prediabetes

Blood glucose targets for people with diabetes should be pre-meal levels between 4-8 mmol/L and 2 hours post-meal levels of less than 10 mmol/L. People with diabetes do not need to go on a special diet, but should understand how different foods affect their blood glucose levels, especially carbohydrates. Diabetic retinopathy is a diabetic eye disease that results from reduced blood flow to the light-sensing nerve layer of the eye (retina). All individuals with diabetes are at risk of developing diabetic retinopathy, but those with poorly controlled diabetes are at higher risk. To control diabetes, it is important to control your HbA1c, Blood Pressure and Cholesterol levels. Hypoglycaemia can be caused by physical activities, missed meals, or other conditions like renal impairment. Continuous Blood Glucose monitoring can help detect asymptomatic or nocturnal hypoglycaemia and aid in adjustments of medication and insulin doses. Metformin and Sulphonylureas are two common medications for diabetes, with side effects of nausea and diarrhoea, and hypoglycaemia and weight gain respectively. Insulin pens should be stored at room temperature with a maximum storage temperature of approximately 25-30 Degrees Celsius, and should be

When a person has diabetes, their body is unable to use insulin to convert stored glucose or glycogen into fuel. As a result, the body will use fat as an energy source, leading to weight loss. Common gastro-intestinal problems associated with diabetes include constipation, indigestion, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. Diabetes can also affect vision, leading to glaucoma, retinopathy, and cataracts. Numbness in the extremities is an early sign of diabetes, and can be caused by poor blood circulation. Diabetes can also lead to impotence in men. Kidneys are the main excretory organs, and filter the blood, removing urea and waste products, excess sugar, salts, and water in the urine. Certain fruit or vegetable juices, Chinese herbs, and medicine may not lower blood glucose levels, but fibre can. It is important to read food labels carefully, as “no sugar” and “sugar-free” have different meanings. Insulin resistance occurs when body cells do not react properly to insulin, and can be caused by obesity, lack of exercise, ethnicity, certain diseases, steroid use, some medications, older age, sleep problems, and smoking.
